div.head: So what exactly is the TEI?
div.p: Originally, Text Encoding for Interchange ... an initiative intended to produce recommendations which would

list.item:
facilitate thecreation, exchange, and integration of textual data in digital form
every kind of text
in every language
for any purpose, from any culture

The TEI recommendations are intended for ...
beginners, seeking well-established solutions to well-understood problems
experts, seeking to create new solutions

div.head: Its original design goals

list.item: provide recommendations derived from the existing consensus, where this could be determined
prefers general solutions to discipline-specific ones
supporting both specialisation and extension

div.p: The TEI was not designed to provide a complete answer "out of the box"

div.head: Where did the TEI come from ?

list.item:
In the 1990s, it was one of the first major projects in the research community later to be known as "digital humanities"...
sponsored by three professional associations (ACL, ACH, ALLC)
Financed 1990-1994 by the NEH, EU LE Programme and SSHRC

Major influences
digital libraries and archives
language engineering
scholarly editing of literary and historical sources

div.head: The TEI now

list.item: International membership consortium established 2000 (voir http://www.tei-c.org/)
The TEI Guidelines, originally envisaged as a single (large) reference manual, increasingly used as a modular online resource
The Guidelines embody a broad consensus about the significant particularities of a huge range of textual materials
expressed both in prose and by means of formal definitions constituting a kind of ontology

the definitions can be expressed as a grammar or schema:
TEI P1-P3 (1991-1999) : SGML DTD
TEI P4 (2000) : SGML or XML DTD
TEI P5 (2005-) XML DTD, W3C Schema, or RelaxNG
The TEI is a modular system, which must be customized for particular applications

div.p: ... the TEI is owned and developed by an active international community
